text: [music playing]
LYNN WYATT: Hello.
I'm Lynn Wyatt.

I'm a native Houstonian and
very proud of it-- a Texan
through and through.
[music playing]

And Although I travel
all over the world,
I love to come back to Houston.
[music playing]

Actually, I thought you would
ask me about restaurants,

because somebody that's
new coming to town
wants to know about restaurants.

One of the best
restaurants is Cafe Annie.

It is celebrating 35 years,
which is a long time.

And it's still going
strong-- delicious food.

Then there is another
one called Steak 48.

- Here you go.
it's in the window.

LYNN WYATT: That's known
for its delicious steaks.

And it is in the
River Oaks District,

which is, by the way, a fabulous
place that you have to go to.

Also in the River
Oaks District is

the iPic Theaters, where
you can put a whole meal
between each one of you.

Or you can just
have, like what I do,

popcorn-- my favor food,
popcorn and Champagne.
(CHUCKLES).
[piano playing]

The soul of any
city is its culture.

There are lots of
museums in major cities.
There is only one Rothko Chapel.

It was by Mark Rothko,
who was commissioned

to paint some paintings for the
inside of this octagonal room.

It was a year before Mark
Rothko committed suicide,
but it is so powerful.

That's got to be number one
on your list for culture.
[music playing]
Then there is The Chocolate Bar.

And that's one of my
favorite places to go.
- Perfect.

LYNN WYATT: If you want to get
the most delicious-- any kind
of sweet, any kind of sweet.
I loved it so much.

And I would go, and I
thought, I'm going too fat,
can't go there every day.
Anyway, The Chocolate Bar.
- Yeah.
[music playing]

LYNN WYATT: Texas
has an openness

about it, not just physically,
but mentally as well.

And a Texas girl thinks
that we can do anything.
And I've been raised like that.

But even before I
knew it, I knew it,
if you can say such a thing.

(CHUCKLES) Don't think that
I'm saying Texas brags.
[laughter]
